introduction: Q3 was another exceptional quarter with record revenue of $4.73 billion, up 57% year-on-year, up 22% sequentially and well above our outlook.
Our new NVIDIA Ampere GPU architecture is ramping with excellent demand across our major market platforms.
Q3 was also a landmark quarter, both for us and the industry as a whole, as we announced plans to acquire Arm from SoftBank for $40 billion.
We are incredibly excited about the combined company’s opportunities and we are working through the regulatory approval process.
For today, we will focus our remarks on our quarterly performance.
gaming: Starting with gaming. Revenue was a record $2.27 billion, up 37% year-on-year, up 37% sequentially, and ahead of our high expectations.
Driving strong growth was our new NVIDIA Ampere architecture-based GeForce RTX 30 series of gaming GPUs.
The GeForce RTX 3070, 3080 and 3090 GPUs offer up to two times the performance and two times the power efficiency over the previous Turing-based generation.
Our second generation NVIDIA RTX combines ray tracing and AI to deliver the greatest ever generational leap in performance.
These GPUs have generated amazing reviews and overwhelming demand. PC World called them 'staggeringly powerful', while Newegg cited more traffic than Black Friday.
Many of our retail and e-tail partners sold out instantly, the RTX 30 series drove our biggest ever launch.
While we anticipated strong demand, it exceeded even our bullish expectations.
Given industry-wide capacity constraints and long cycle times, it may take a few more months for product availability to catch up with demand.
In addition to the NVIDIA Ampere GPU architecture, we announced powerful new tools for gamers, live streamers, eSports professionals, artists and creators.

NVIDIA Reflex improves reaction time in games, reducing system latency by up to 58%. It is being integrated into popular eSports games such as Apex Legends, Call of Duty: Warzone, Fortnite and Valorant.
NVIDIA Broadcast is a universal plugin for video conferencing and live streaming applications that enhances the quality of microphones, speakers and webcams with NVIDIA AI effects.

Blockbuster games continue to adopt NVIDIA’s RTX ray tracing and AI technology. Epic Games announced that Fortnite is adding NVIDIA RTX real-time ray tracing, DLSS AI super-resolution and NVIDIA Reflex.
Other major new titles featuring RTX this holiday season include Watch Dogs: Legion, Call of Duty: Black Ops Cold War, and Cyberpunk 2077.
Gaming laptop demand was also strong with double-digit year-on-year growth for the 11th quarter in a row.
NVIDIA GeForce laptops support the most demanding applications for creators and designers while doubling as a powerful gaming system.
We also have record gaming console revenue on strong demand for the Nintendo Switch.
We continue to grow our cloud gaming service, GeForce NOW, which has doubled in the past seven months to reach over 5 million registered users.
GeForce NOW is unique as an open platform connecting to popular game stores, giving gamers access to titles they already own.
750 games are currently available on GFN, including 75 free-to-play games, with more added every Thursday.
GFN supports many popular clients, including PCs, Macs, and Chromebooks. Stay tuned for more devices to come.
GFN’s reach expands through telco partners in Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Russia, and Saudi Arabia.
Following our earlier announcement with Tencent, Amazon and Facebook are beginning to offer cloud gaming services powered by NVIDIA.
proviz: Moving to ProViz, Q3 revenue was $236 million, down 27% year-on-year and up 16% sequentially, ahead of our expectations.
Sequential growth was driven by strength in notebooks, which posted record revenue, boosted by work-from-home initiatives and a shift to thin and light mobile workstations.
This was partially offset by a decline in desktop workstations, which continued to be impacted by the pandemic and drove the year-on-year decline.
From an industry demand perspective, stronger verticals include healthcare, public sector, higher education and research, and financial services.
We continue to win new business in areas like healthcare (Medtronic for visual surgical applications), medical imaging, technology, media, and entertainment.
During the quarter, we announced Omniverse, the world’s first 3D collaboration and simulation platform, entering open beta.
Omniverse enables tens of millions of designers, architects and creators to collaborate in real time, on-premises or remotely.
Fusing the virtual and physical worlds, Omniverse brings together NVIDIA breakthroughs in graphics, simulation and AI.
It will help enterprises address evolving requirements as workforces become increasingly distributed.
Over 400 individual creators and developers in diverse industries have been evaluating Omniverse. Early adopters include Ericsson, BMW, Foster and Partners, and Lucasfilm.
The pandemic is accelerating development of AR, VR, and mixed reality, which will have a profound impact on how we work and play.
Our work with NASCAR to enable AR and VR services at the edge is revolutionizing the racing experience for millions of fans.
automotive: Moving to automotive, Q3 revenue was $125 million, down 23% year-on-year and up 13% sequentially.
Sequential growth was driven by a recovery in global automotive production volumes, as well as continued growth in AI cockpit revenue.
The year-on-year decline was due to the expected ramp-down of legacy infotainment revenue.
In September, Mercedes-Benz debuted its redesigned S-class sedan, featuring an all-new NVIDIA powered MBUX AI cockpit system.
Li Auto announced that it will develop its next generation of vehicles using the software-defined NVIDIA DRIVE AGX Orin platform.
Orin delivers nearly 7 times the performance and 3 times the energy efficiency of our previous generation SOC.
NVIDIA has excellent traction with EV startups.
NVIDIA and Hyundai Motor Group announced that the automaker’s entire lineup will come standard with NVIDIA DRIVE infotainment systems starting in 2022.
data_center: Now moving to Data Center. Revenue was a record $1.9 billion, up 162% year-over-year and up 8% sequentially.
Growth was driven by a strong ramp of our A100-based platforms, continued growth with Mellanox, and record T4 shipments for inference.
Our new NVIDIA Ampere architecture gained adoption by cloud and hyperscale customers and started ramping into vertical industries.
AWS, Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, and Alibaba Cloud announced general availability of the A100, following Google Cloud and Microsoft Azure.
A100 adoption by vertical industries drove strong growth as we began shipments to server OEM partners who have broad enterprise channels.
We ramped the DGX A100 server and began shipping NVIDIA DGX SuperPOD, the first turnkey AI infrastructure.
These range from 20 to 140 DGX A100 systems interconnected with Mellanox’s HDR InfiniBand networking, enabling installation of powerful AI supercomputers in just a few weeks.
We announced plans to build Cambridge-1, an 80-node DGX SuperPOD with 400 petaflops of AI performance, to be the UK’s fastest AI supercomputer.
Cambridge-1 will be used by NVIDIA researchers for collaborative research within the UK’s AI and healthcare community.
It joins other systems in NVIDIA’s complex of AI supercomputers used for R&D in autonomous vehicles, conversational AI, robotics, graphics, HPC and other domains.
Selene is now the world’s fifth fastest supercomputer and fastest commercial supercomputer.
A new NVIDIA DGX SuperPOD ranks first on the Green500 list of the world’s most energy efficient supercomputers.
We formed a new partnership with GSK for AI-driven drug and vaccine discovery. GSK’s AI hub will use NVIDIA’s DGX A100 systems and have access to Cambridge-1 and NVIDIA scientists.
In Q3, the A100 swept the industry standard MLPerf benchmark for AI inference performance, following our previous success in training benchmarks.
For ResNet-50 image recognition, our A100 GPU beat CPU-only systems by 30x this year vs. 6x last year.
In the newly added recommendation model test, A100 outperformed CPUs by up to 237x.
Our winning performance in AI inference translates to continued strong revenue growth.
Alongside A100’s ramp, T4 sales set a record as NVIDIA AI inference adoption is in full throttle.
We estimate that NVIDIA’s installed GPU capacity for inference across the seven largest public clouds now exceeds their aggregate CPU capacity.
Hundreds of companies operate AI-enabled services on NVIDIA inference platforms, including Tencent, Microsoft, and American Express.
We also gained tremendous traction in supercomputing. NVIDIA technology will power five systems awarded by EuroHPC.
CINECA in Italy will use NVIDIA’s accelerated computing platform to build the world’s fastest AI supercomputer, named Leonardo, delivering 10 exaflops of AI performance.
NVIDIA GPUs or networking power 70% of the Top500 supercomputers, including 8 of the top 10.
mellanox: Mellanox had another record quarter with double-digit sequential growth, contributing 13% of overall Company revenue.
Upside included sales to a China OEM that will not recur in Q4.
We expect a meaningful sequential revenue decline from Mellanox in Q4, but still 30% growth from last year.
Mellanox reached record revenue in both InfiniBand and Ethernet, driven by cloud, enterprise and supercomputing customers.
Strong demand for high-performance interconnects is fueled by AI’s increasingly complex applications.
As the data center becomes the new unit of computing in the age of AI, Mellanox networking is foundational to modern scalable architectures.
dpus_and_product_launches: At GTC in October, we unveiled the BlueField-2 DPU, a new kind of processor that offloads critical networking, storage and security tasks from the CPU.
A single BlueField-2 DPU can deliver the same data center services that consume up to 125 CPU cores.
This frees valuable CPU cores and enables zero trust security features and accelerates performance.
VMware will offload, accelerate, and isolate its ESXi hypervisor using BlueField-2, boosting data center performance and efficiency.
We unveiled our three-year DPU roadmap and introduced NVIDIA DOCA, a data-center-on-a-chip architecture software development kit.
We believe DPUs will ship in millions of servers, unlocking a $10 billion total addressable market.
BlueField-2 is sampling now with major hyperscale customers and will be integrated into enterprise server offerings.
At Supercomputing 2020, we announced A100 80GB GPUs and DGX systems for building, training, and deploying massive AI models.
We also announced DGX Station A100, a powerful workgroup server for data scientists and AI researchers working remotely.
All these Ampere-based additions will be available early next year.
We announced NVIDIA Mellanox 400Gb/s InfiniBand architecture, doubling data throughput and adding in-network computing engines. Solutions based on this are expected to sample in Q2 CY2021.
financials: Q3 GAAP gross margin was 62.6% and non-GAAP gross margin was 65.5%.
GAAP gross margin declined YoY primarily due to Mellanox acquisition charges, partially offset by product mix.
The sequential increase in GAAP gross margin was due to the absence of non-recurring inventory step-up expense related to the Mellanox acquisition.
Non-GAAP gross margin increased by 140 basis points YoY, reflecting a shift in product mix with higher data center sales, including Mellanox.
Non-GAAP gross margin was down 50 basis points sequentially, in line with expectations, driven by product mix.
Q3 GAAP operating expenses were $1.56 billion and non-GAAP operating expenses were $1.1 billion.
GAAP operating expenses were up 6% YoY, non-GAAP up 42% YoY.
Q3 GAAP EPS was $2.12, up 46% YoY, and non-GAAP EPS was $2.91, up 63% YoY.
Q3 cash flow from operations was $1.28 billion.
q4_outlook: Q4 includes a 14th week, expected to incrementally add to revenue and operating expenses.
We expect gaming to be up sequentially in what is typically a seasonally down quarter, as we continue to ramp up RTX 30 Series.
We expect data center to be down slightly vs. Q3.
Computing products are expected to grow mid-single-digit sequentially, offset by a sequential decline in Mellanox.
We expect continued sequential growth in auto and ProViz, but not yet returning to YoY growth.
We expect a seasonal decline in OEM.
Revenue is expected to be $4.8 billion, plus or minus 2%.
GAAP and non-GAAP gross margins expected at 62.8% and 65.5%, respectively, plus or minus 50 bps.
GAAP and non-GAAP operating expenses expected to be approximately $1.64 billion and $1.18 billion.
GAAP and non-GAAP other income and expenses are expected to be an expense of ~$55 million.
GAAP and non-GAAP tax rates expected to be 8% ±1%, excluding discrete items.
Capital expenditures expected to be ~$300 million to $325 million.
investor_relations: We will be attending the Credit Suisse Technology Conference on November 30th, the Wells Fargo TMT Summit on December 1st, and the UBS TMT Conference on December 7th.
Our earnings call to discuss the fourth quarter and full-year results is scheduled for Wednesday, February 24th.
